addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord,
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England

xi De
c
1591
. M
r
Bodeleye to my L.
Copie of
e Ambassado
rs
second l
re
& awnswere./.

page.lettertext:
fol.276r
May it please yo
r
good L. I have heerewith
inclosed
e copie of an other letter from
e Em-
pero
rs
Ambassado
rs
, to
e
General states
. The
letter was receaved and read by suche as are
autorised unto it in
e absence of
e Deputies. But
because there meeting is adjourned till
e 20 of
De
c
and their appearance is commonly about
fortnight after, and perhaps in regard of this pour-
s uit of
e Empero
rs
will be further prolonged,
there is no other answear made unto
e Ambassa-
do
rs
, then I have sent unto yo
w
w
t
the letter: w
ch
is a note of Receat, from
e
Greffier
of
e states
delivered to
e Trompet,
at brought
e letter hither.
Heere is great inquirie among many, to heare
howe her
Ma
tie
is affected in
e cause: but I knowe
not directly what to answear unto them, not
having yet receaved any instruction from yo
r
L:
w
ch
maketh me sparing in delivering my opinion
Howbeit I doe alwaies incline to
at whiche heereto-
fore I have bin willed to persuade, That her Hig
nes
is unwilling to hearcken to any Treaty, unles
it may be general, aswell for her self, as for them,
and also for
France.
Of
e Enemies
actions in these contreis, heere is nothing certaine:
It is onely reported,
at
e
D. of Parma
is de-
parted from
Brussels
towardes
Mons
in
Henault,
to goe forward for Fraunce: albeit his voiage
thither, is greatly doubted of many.
And
thus for this present I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. De
c
11 1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
